More common is 5.a3 Bxc3 6.bxc3 c5 with good counter attack for black on queenside.
moves.5... b6: Looking to trade off his bad light squared bishop
moves.6. Nce2: The idea is to avoid exchange of light squared bishops and transfer the knight to the kingside for attack on black's king. Also by forcing black to exchanges dark squared bishops white gains more control than black on the dark squares because his queen is on a more active dark square than black's queen.
moves.6... Bxd2+ 7. Qxd2 Ba6 8. f4: Gains space and Increases white control on darks squares as well supporting e5.
moves.8... c5 9. Nf3 Nbc6 10. c3 Nf5: Nf5?!  Black could have equalized the game after 10...0-0 11.Ng3 Bxf1 12.Rxf1 f6 13.Kf2 fxe5 14.fxe5 Ng6 15.Kg1 Qe7 16.Rf2 Nh4 17.Raf1 Nxf3+ 18.Rxf3 Rxf3 19.Rxf3 Rf8 20.Rxf8+ Qxf8+ 21.Ne2 Qf5 ...Marjanovic,S(2540)-Psakhis(2540) Bor 1985
moves.11. O-O-O h5: Usually in this variation the long castling is unprofitable for white, because black exchanges his bad "French" bishop and close the position reciving excellent prospects for massive pawn attack on the white king: 11.Bxe2 12.Bxe2 c4. However, here we see that black hastened with Nf5 move and this fact give white a few extra tempo- 13.g4 Nh4 14.Rdf1 Nxg3 15.Rxf3 b5 16.f5 b4 17.fxe6 fxe6 18.Qf4 Qe7 19.Rhf1 Kd7 20.Qf7 Rhf8 21.Bd1 Rxf7 22.Rxf7 bxc3 23.bxc3 =
moves.12. Ng3: And now white captures the black knight, so the royal fortess suffers damage.
moves.12... Bxf1: Better than 12...Nxg3 13.hxg3 Bxf1 14.Rdxf1 cxd4 15.cxd4 Qc7 16.Kb1 0-0 17.Ng5! Qd7 18.f5 exf5 19.Qc2 Kb8 20.Qxf5 Qxf5+ 21.Rxf5 Nxd4 22.Rf4! Ne2 23.Nxf7 Nxf4 24.gxf4 Kc7 25.Kc2 Rhf8 26.Nxd8 Kxd8 27.g3 g5 28.fxg5 Ke7 29.Rxh5 Rf2+ 30.Kc3 Ke6 31.Kd4 Kf5 32.g4+ Kxg4 33.Rh8 Kxg5 34.Rg8+ Kh6 35.e6 Re2 36.Kxd5 winning
moves.13. Nxf5 exf5 14. Rhxf1 c4: From here black's strategy is to blockade the position with Nd8-Ne6
moves.15... Qe7 16. Rde1 Nd8: The fact that black has not castle and place his pieces on good squares show that he judge the opening position wrong.
moves.18. Nf3 g6 19. Nh4 Rg8 20. Rf3 Nb7: 20...Nb7?! Harder could be protected by 20...0nc6 21.Rg3 Qh7 22.b3 cxb3 23.axb3 0-0-0 although here white retains the advantage due to the strong passed pawn and dynamic center.
moves.21. Rg3 Nd6 22. Rxg6: Much stronger was 22.Qd1 0-0-0 23.Nxg6 Qe8 24.Qxh5 Ne4 25.Rxe4 fxe4 26.Qf5 and pawn avalanche is unstoppable.
moves.22... Rxg6 23. Nxg6 Qh7 24. Nh4 O-O-O: Strong redoubts making by 24...Ne4 25.Qc2 b5 26.b3 Rc8 27.Kb2 a6 28.b4 Ke7 29.a4 Kxe6 30.axb5 axb5 31.Ra1 Qb7 32.Qd1 Ra8 33.g3 Rxa1 34.Qxa1 Qe7
